unnormalised: Planning a trip? Budgeting your travel expenses in India can be trickier than convincing your relatives you don't need to "settle down" yet! It’s a land where a fancy hotel might cost you ₹15,000 a night, while a delicious plate of street-side pani puri sets you back a mere ₹30. Welcome to the glorious, chaotic, and oh-so-affordable (or wildly expensive) world of Indian travel finances.

Welcome to the glorious, chaotic, and oh-so-affordable (or wildly expensive) world of Indian travel finances.

unnormalised: First, flights. Booking in advance is your best friend. Seriously, set those Google Flights alerts! A round trip from Delhi to Goa could range from ₹6,000 (if you book 3 months ahead and pray to the travel gods) to ₹18,000 (if you decide to spontaneously fly tomorrow because, well, why not?). Internal travel can sometimes cost more than international. Irony, much?

unnormalised: Next up, accommodation. Forget your Western concepts of "budget" hotels. In India, "budget" can mean anything from a charming guesthouse run by a chai-loving grandpa charging ₹800 a night to a hostel bunk that resembles a sardine can (but with more snoring) for ₹500. Mid-range hotels (think Oyo Rooms, but with a slightly higher chance of clean sheets) usually hover around ₹2,000-₹4,000.

Mid-range hotels (think O-Y-O Rooms, but with a slightly higher chance of clean sheets) usually hover around rupee two thousand-rupee four thousand.

unnormalised: Food! Oh, glorious food! This is where your wallet can simultaneously weep tears of joy and despair. A lavish thali at a restaurant might cost you ₹500, but trust me, the sheer volume of food will keep you fueled for a trek across Rajasthan. Street food is the true king (or queen!). Samosas for ₹10, chai for ₹15, and enough questionable-but-delicious snacks to make your stomach question your life choices. Don’t forget to factor in the cost of antacids… approximately ₹50.

Samosas for rupee ten, chai for rupee fifteen, and enough questionable-but-delicious snacks to make your stomach question your life choices. Do not forget to factor in the cost of antacids… approximately rupee fifty.

unnormalised: Transportation: Brace yourself for a wild ride. Auto-rickshaws are the pulse of every Indian city. Haggle like your life depends on it! A short ride should cost you around ₹60-₹80. Ola and Uber are readily available in most cities, usually costing around ₹15 per kilometer. But honestly, an auto ride is a cultural experience you just can’t miss, even if you feel like you're participating in the world's most chaotic Grand Prix. Local trains are super cheap and a great way to get around the metro cities - a local train ride from Churchgate to Borivali in Mumbai might only cost ₹20.

unnormalised: Activities and Entrance Fees: Visiting historical sites like the Taj Mahal will set you back around ₹1100 if you are not an Indian citizen. Smaller temples and forts usually have nominal fees of around ₹50-₹200. Remember to factor in the "photo tax" that some places charge… because apparently, memories aren't enough anymore!

unnormalised: Finally, the miscellaneous expenses. Because India, you’ll inevitably encounter unexpected costs. Souvenirs (bargain hard!), that extra chai you couldn't resist (₹15), the bribe you had to pay to a traffic cop because you forgot your license (₹500 – maybe?), and the inevitable donation to a roadside temple (₹20). Oh, and don’t forget the emergency fund for that sudden craving for imported chocolate (Rs 250) after a week of street food.

unnormalised: So, how much should you budget for a trip to India? Well, that depends on your tolerance for adventure (and street food). A shoestring budget can be done for as little as ₹1000 per day. A comfortable mid-range trip will probably cost you around ₹3000-₹5000 per day. And if you’re planning on living like royalty, well, the sky’s the limit! Just remember to pack your bargaining skills, your sense of humor, and a whole lot of hand sanitizer. Happy travels, and may your rupee stretch further than a yoga instructor in Rishikesh!
